Article.ArticleTitle: Ambient Air Pollution in Relation to SARS-CoV-2 Infection, Antibody Response, and COVID-19 Disease: A Cohort Study in Catalonia, Spain (COVICAT Study).

AbstractText: Emerging evidence links ambient air pollution with coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) disease, an association that is methodologically challenging to investigate.

We examined the association between long-term exposure to air pollution with SARS-CoV-2 infection measured through antibody response, level of antibody response among those infected, and COVID-19 disease.

We contacted 9,605 adult participants from a population-based cohort study in Catalonia between June and November 2020; most participants were between 40 and 65 years of age. We drew blood samples from 4,103 participants and measured immunoglobulin M (IgM), IgA, and IgG antibodies against five viral target antigens to establish infection to the virus and levels of antibody response among those infected. We defined COVID-19 disease using self-reported hospital admission, prior positive diagnostic test, or more than three self-reported COVID-19 symptoms after contact with a COVID-19 case. We estimated prepandemic (2018-2019) exposure to fine particulate matter [PM with an aerodynamic diameter of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mspace></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mi>m</mi></mrow></math> (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math>)], nitrogen dioxide (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>), black carbon (BC), and ozone (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>) at the residential address using hybrid land-use regression models. We calculated log-binomial risk ratios (RRs), adjusting for individual- and area-level covariates.

Among those tested for SARS-CoV-2 antibodies, 743 (18.1%) were seropositive. Air pollution levels were not statistically significantly associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection: Adjusted RRs per interquartile range were 1.07 (95% CI: 0.97, 1.18) for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, 1.04 (95% CI: 0.94, 1.14) for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, 1.00 (95% CI: 0.92, 1.09) for BC, and 0.97 (95% CI: 0.89, 1.06) for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>. Among infected participants, exposure to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math> were positively associated with IgG levels for all viral target antigens. Among all participants, 481 (5.0%) had COVID-19 disease. Air pollution levels were associated with COVID-19 disease: adjusted <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>RRs</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1.14</mn></mrow></math> (95% CI: 1.00, 1.29) for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and 1.17 (95% CI: 1.03, 1.32) for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math>. Exposure to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> was associated with a slightly decreased risk (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>RR</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>0.92</mn></mrow></math>; 95% CI: 0.83, 1.03). Associations of air pollution with COVID-19 disease were more pronounced for severe COVID-19, with <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>RRs</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1.26</mn></mrow></math> (95% CI: 0.89, 1.79) for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and 1.51 (95% CI: 1.06, 2.16) for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math>.
Exposure to air pollution was associated with a higher risk of COVID-19 disease and level of antibody response among infected but not with SARS-CoV-2 infection. https://doi.org/10.1289/EHP9726.
